Hong Kong Protesters Taking Greater Risks to Challenge Beijing

Hundreds arrested as demonstrations against two controversial bills pop up across city

Fol­low­ing smaller street protests Sun­day, a leg­isla­tive de­bate Wednes­day of a bill that would crim­i­nal­ize dis­re­spect of Chi­na’s na­tional an­them was an op­por­tu­nity to see how far pro­testers re­main will­ing to go in the face of re­stric­tions on pub­lic gath­er­ings, po­lice ar­rest squads and the threat of the na­tional-se­cu­rity law hang­ing over dis­si­dents. More than 8,000 pro­testers ar­rested dur­ing the past year al­ready face lengthy jail sen­tences as their cases get pro­cessed through the courts.

Still, pro­testers—many of them young—joined spo­radic demon­stra­tions across the city through­out Wednes­day. At lunchtime, hun­dreds of pro­testers turned up in the cen­tral busi­ness dis­trict, which was as usual bustling with of­fice work­ers and shop­pers. For a few min­utes, they rushed out into the street—stop­ping taxis and buses—and chant­ing “Fight for Free­dom! Stand With Hong Kong!” Many held up five fin­gers, a sym­bol of the five de­mands that un­der­pin the move­ment, which in­clude greater de­mo­c­ra­tic rights and more po­lice ac­count­abil­ity.
